project.name: readme-stats
project.description: A zero-config CLI that scores your README against best practices and tells you exactly what's missing

milestones.name: Phase 2: Core Features
milestones.description: README analysis, scoring system, and CLI output

issues.title: Initialize Node.js project with package.json
issues.body:
## Description

Set up the initial Node.js project structure for the readme-stats CLI tool.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] package.json created with appropriate name, version, description
- [ ] `bin` field configured for CLI entry point (`readme-stats`)
- [ ] `type: module` set for ES modules (or CommonJS if preferred)
- [ ] .gitignore configured for Node.js
- [ ] MIT license file added
- [ ] Basic folder structure created

## Technical Notes

- Keep dependencies minimal per spec (chalk for colors OR zero-dep with ANSI codes)
- Consider using `#!/usr/bin/env node` shebang
- Entry point should be `index.js` or `bin/readme-stats.js`

issues.title: Set up CLI argument parsing
issues.body:
## Description

Implement basic CLI argument handling to accept an optional file path argument.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] CLI accepts optional path argument (defaults to `./README.md`)
- [ ] `--help` flag shows usage information
- [ ] `--version` flag shows package version
- [ ] Invalid arguments show helpful error message

## Technical Notes

- Can use `process.argv` directly to keep zero-dep
- No need for heavy CLI framework for this simple use case
- Usage: `readme-stats [path/to/README.md]`

## Dependencies

- Depends on: Project initialization (#1)

issues.title: Implement README file reader
issues.body:
## Description

Create functionality to read README.md from the filesystem.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Reads file from current directory by default
- [ ] Reads file from specified path if provided
- [ ] Graceful error handling if file not found
- [ ] Graceful error handling if file not readable
- [ ] Returns file content as string

## Technical Notes

- Use `fs.readFileSync` or `fs.promises.readFile`
- Check file exists before reading
- Handle encoding (UTF-8)

## Dependencies

- Depends on: CLI argument parsing (#2)

issues.title: Implement section detection with regex patterns
issues.body:
## Description

Create regex-based detection system to identify README sections by heading patterns.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Detects Title (H1 heading or first line)
- [ ] Detects Description (content after title, before first H2)
- [ ] Detects Installation section ("Install", "Installation", "Setup", "Getting Started")
- [ ] Detects Usage section ("Usage", "How to Use", "Examples")
- [ ] Detects License section ("License", "Licensing")
- [ ] Detects Contributing section ("Contributing", "Contribute", "Contributors")
- [ ] Detects Badges (shield.io links, badge images in first 20 lines)
- [ ] Detects Table of Contents ("Table of Contents", "TOC", "Contents")
- [ ] Case-insensitive matching
- [ ] Handles both `#` and underline-style headings

## Technical Notes

- Create a map of section types to regex patterns
- Consider variations mentioned in spec
- Return object with detected sections and their line numbers

## Dependencies

- Depends on: README file reader (#3)

issues.title: Implement scoring system
issues.body:
## Description

Create the scoring algorithm that assigns points based on detected sections.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] High value sections (20 pts each): Title, Description, Installation, Usage
- [ ] Medium value sections (10 pts each): License, Contributing
- [ ] Low value sections (5 pts each): Badges, Table of Contents
- [ ] TOC only scored if README > 200 lines
- [ ] Maximum score is 100 points
- [ ] Returns breakdown of points per section
- [ ] Returns list of missing sections

## Technical Notes

- Score calculation: present sections sum their points
- Handle edge case where all sections present (cap at 100)
- Consider: 4×20 + 2×10 + 2×5 = 110 max, so normalize or adjust weights
- Alternative: Only count TOC toward 100 if file > 200 lines

## Dependencies

- Depends on: Section detection (#4)

issues.title: Implement colored CLI output
issues.body:
## Description

Create formatted, colored terminal output for the analysis results.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Display overall score prominently
- [ ] Green color for score > 80
- [ ] Yellow color for score 51-80
- [ ] Red color for score ≤ 50
- [ ] List all detected sections with checkmarks
- [ ] List missing sections with X marks
- [ ] Show suggestions for each missing section
- [ ] Output completes in under 1 second

## Technical Notes

- Option 1: Use `chalk` package for colors
- Option 2: Use raw ANSI escape codes for zero-dep
- ANSI codes: `\x1b[32m` (green), `\x1b[33m` (yellow), `\x1b[31m` (red), `\x1b[0m` (reset)
- Consider non-TTY output (no colors when piped)

## Dependencies

- Depends on: Scoring system (#5)

issues.title: Create suggestions for missing sections
issues.body:
## Description

Provide helpful, actionable suggestions for each missing section.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Title suggestion: explains importance of clear project name
- [ ] Description suggestion: what to include in description
- [ ] Installation suggestion: example commands to include
- [ ] Usage suggestion: code examples recommendation
- [ ] License suggestion: common licenses to consider
- [ ] Contributing suggestion: what to include
- [ ] Badges suggestion: common badges to add
- [ ] TOC suggestion: when and how to add

## Technical Notes

- Keep suggestions concise (1-2 sentences)
- Make them actionable ("Add a ## Installation section with...")
- Store as simple object/map for easy maintenance

## Dependencies

- Depends on: Section detection (#4)

issues.title: Add unit tests for section detection
issues.body:
## Description

Create comprehensive tests for the regex-based section detection.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Test each section type detection
- [ ] Test heading variations ("Install" vs "Installation")
- [ ] Test case insensitivity
- [ ] Test H1/H2 with # syntax
- [ ] Test underline-style headings (===, ---)
- [ ] Test edge cases (empty file, no headings)
- [ ] All tests pass

## Technical Notes

- Use Node.js built-in test runner (`node:test`) for zero-dep
- Or use minimal test framework if preferred
- Create sample README fixtures for testing

## Dependencies

- Depends on: Section detection (#4)

issues.title: Add unit tests for scoring system
issues.body:
## Description

Create tests for the scoring algorithm.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Test perfect README (all sections) = 100
- [ ] Test empty README = 0
- [ ] Test partial README scores correctly
- [ ] Test TOC scoring with <200 lines (not counted)
- [ ] Test TOC scoring with >200 lines (counted)
- [ ] Test score breakdown accuracy

## Technical Notes

- Use same test framework as section detection tests
- Create mock section detection results

## Dependencies

- Depends on: Scoring system (#5)
- Depends on: Section detection tests (#8)

issues.title: Add integration tests with sample READMEs
issues.body:
## Description

Create end-to-end tests with real-world README examples.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Test against minimal README (just title)
- [ ] Test against complete README (all sections)
- [ ] Test against popular open source README styles
- [ ] Test against README with unusual formatting
- [ ] All tests complete in under 1 second total

## Technical Notes

- Create `test/fixtures/` directory with sample READMEs
- Test CLI output formatting
- Consider snapshot testing for output

## Dependencies

- Depends on: Colored CLI output (#6)

issues.title: Write README for readme-stats
issues.body:
## Description

Create a comprehensive README that demonstrates the tool's own best practices (and scores 100!).

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Clear title and description
- [ ] Installation instructions (npm install)
- [ ] Usage examples with sample output
- [ ] Scoring criteria documentation
- [ ] Section variations table
- [ ] License section
- [ ] Contributing section
- [ ] Badges (npm version, license, etc.)
- [ ] README scores 100 with the tool itself

## Technical Notes

- This is a great opportunity to dogfood the tool
- Include screenshot or ASCII art of sample output
- Keep it concise but complete

## Dependencies

- Depends on: All Phase 2 features complete

issues.title: Prepare for npm publishing
issues.body:
## Description

Finalize package.json and prepare for npm publish.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] package.json has correct `name` (check npm availability)
- [ ] package.json has `keywords` for discoverability
- [ ] package.json has `repository`, `bugs`, `homepage` fields
- [ ] `files` field specifies what to publish
- [ ] .npmignore or files field excludes tests/dev files
- [ ] `npm pack` produces clean tarball
- [ ] `npx readme-stats` works after local install

## Technical Notes

- Check if `readme-stats` is available on npm
- Alternative names: `readme-score`, `readme-check`, `readme-lint`
- Test with `npm link` locally

## Dependencies

- Depends on: README complete (#11)
- Depends on: All tests passing (#8, #9, #10)

issues.title: Handle edge case: no README found
issues.body:
## Description

Provide helpful output when no README.md exists in the target directory.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Clear error message when file not found
- [ ] Suggest creating a README
- [ ] List the sections that should be included
- [ ] Exit with non-zero code

## Technical Notes

- Could offer to create a template README (stretch goal, out of MVP scope)
- Error should be red-colored

## Dependencies

- Depends on: README file reader (#3)

issues.title: Handle edge case: binary or non-text files
issues.body:
## Description

Gracefully handle when the specified file is not a valid text file.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Detect non-UTF8 or binary content
- [ ] Show appropriate error message
- [ ] Exit with non-zero code

## Technical Notes

- Check for null bytes or invalid UTF-8 sequences
- This is a defensive measure, unlikely in practice

## Dependencies

- Depends on: README file reader (#3)

issues.title: Add --no-color flag for CI environments
issues.body:
## Description

Allow users to disable colored output for CI/CD pipelines or logging.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `--no-color` flag disables ANSI codes
- [ ] Auto-detect non-TTY and disable colors
- [ ] Respects `NO_COLOR` environment variable
- [ ] Output remains readable without colors

## Technical Notes

- Check `process.stdout.isTTY`
- Check `process.env.NO_COLOR`
- This helps future CI integration (even though out of MVP scope)

## Dependencies

- Depends on: Colored CLI output (#6)
